text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new Matt
DeMarco record salad days this is the
latest full-length LP from
singer/songwriter Mac DeMarco following
up his modestly successful full-length
LP - which turned him into a pretty
massive personality in the jangle pop
world and I say personality because
between numerous music videos and
interviews that he's done since the
release of this really lacks easygoing
record he has come off really eccentric
playful hilarious Mac DeMarcos persona
to me is so enjoyable that I can only
hope that his music continues to stay
relevant just so that one day I can sort
of see his goofy smile on a billboard
somewhere now I didn't love his last
record but I did think it had some
fantastic tracks on it tracks that made
for great singles great music videos
like my kind of woman
or Oh - Viceroy or dreaming really
gentle combination of bass and drums
twinkling guitars were some really
expressive strumming the whole vibe was
really chill however the melodies on
these tracks and sometimes the lyrics
and the song concepts but mostly the
melody is really sharp
I was hoping Mac would come through
develop a bit more on his next record
drop some stronger singles bring a
little more variety to the table but
personally I do not feel like that
happen I think Mac came through with an
even more homogenous record than he did
with - not only that but I think this
record has less single power as well
I mean sonically melodically I don't
think there's a single song on this
record that rivals one of the better
tracks on - and I think with Mac putting
out more music touring more signing with
captured tracks
he's almost lost the spontaneity that
was there on some of his stuff like rock
and roll nightclub Mac's really smooth
gentle easygoing sound seems to be the
only likable quality about his music
that has stuck around for this record
then some of the different song topics
that he tends to address over the course
record some of which may not be apparent
from first listen just because of how
emotionally disconnected and just sigh
of relief this whole album feels in
terms of its vocal delivery there are
some true heartbreak songs on this LP
however emotionally it doesn't really
feel that way necessarily because the
the emotional pain doesn't really ring
through all of the sonic lethargy that I
think the instrumentation brings and
that's unfortunate you know I understand
that to was a really big breakout record
for Mac but I think salad days kind of
shows where his ambitions lie at the end
of the day salad days just feels like a
hit of the reset button it's a record
that acts like its predecessor never
even existed even the songs that I like
off of this thing I feel like I'm merely
enjoying them just because they sound
just like moments off of Mac's previous
album like with the song passing out
pieces which initially grabs my ear
because of its shimmering synthesizer
arpeggios I do love the increase in the
use of synths on this record overall
they do add a really nice touch but as
soon as the twinkling guitar solos pour
through on the course I get this extreme
shot of deja vu and then a pretty
surprised fade-out right after the
second chorus on this track and this
isn't the only track this happens on
unfortunately and in this song in
particular it's like it's really truly
over and done with 30 seconds before it
decides to completely and fully fade out
it's moments like this that make me feel
like Mac DeMarco isn't putting as much
effort into this record as he did his
last record and I'm kind of sitting here
wondering why I feel the same way on the
incredibly underwhelming acoustic ballad
let my baby stay or the song go easy
where essentially the hook is done to
death the intro to the song treater
better extreme deja vu there overall
with the groove on the song blue boy to
either Mac is just unashamedly repeating
past successes in his musical career
that all have occurred very recently or
he's indulging in some really
unenjoyable ideas like the end of the
track
Blueboy which is one of the more sedate
tracks on the entire LP and then all of
a sudden at the very finish this
shoegaze II wall of guitars is hit with
this horrible off pitch falsetto that is
not pleasant to the air in any way
whatsoever honestly I'm pretty on the
fence with this LP I do like the vibe I
do like the sound that Matt continues to
bring to the table but I feel like this
record overall is the sound of not
succeeding not failing horribly but
settling just settling instead of
shooting for something more ambitious
Mac has settled he's settled for dishing
out the kind of tracks that play between
your favorite songs on am soft rock
radio in the 70s he's settled for a redo
he's settled for sounding like a
sleepytime aerial pink and in the
process didn't even finish some of the
tracks here that he started did not give
strong endings to some of these tracks
like I know he has on his previous
efforts there's just a lot of loose ends
on this LP even on the last track of
this LP which is just a kind of
forgettable instrumental we're finally
as the song just decides to stop Mack
pop sentences hey everybody thanks for
listening bye bye which is is is pretty
cute and does show Mack DeMarcos
personality this is something I wish
more artists did however you know I
would much rather have succinct
well-written memorable songs than sort
of this really nice goodbye message so
in its best moments this record is is
very pretty on the ear it's seductive
but in its worst it's redundant it's
stale its unimaginative and it's it's
kind of short of breath - I'm feeling a
light - decent 5 on this thing
transition if you've given this record
to listen what did you think of it did
you love it did you hate it why what do
you think I should review next and
that's it Mack DeMarco salad days
forever
